--- name: derivatives --- ## Definition A [Derivative]{.hii} is simply another function that tells us the slope of a function - It tells us how a function is behaving - A [Derivative]{.hii} will be how we find the slope of our functions . . .
[Mathematically]{.hi} - We will denote a [Derivative]{.hii} as $f'(x)$ - Our original function is labeled $f(x)$ so you can read this as: "The derivative of $f(x)$ is $f'(x)$" - Note that $f'(x)$ is the slope of $f(x)$ at any point $x$ --- ## Intuition ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggplot2) # Create time values time <- seq(0, 10, length.out = 100) # Calculate height values for the parabola height <- -0.5 * (time - 5)^2 + 10 # Create a data frame parabola_data <- data.frame(time, height) # Split the data into increasing and decreasing segments increasing_data <- parabola_data[parabola_data$time <= 5, ] decreasing_data <- parabola_data[parabola_data$time > 5, ] # Create the parabola plot with different colors parabola_plot <- ggplot() + geom_line(data = increasing_data, aes(time, height), color = "#A3BE8C", size = 1) + geom_line(data = decreasing_data, aes(time, height), color = "#BF616A" , size = 1) + theme_minimal() + theme(axis.text.x = element_blank(), # Remove x-axis ticks and labels axis.ticks.x = element_blank(), # Remove x-axis ticks, axis.ticks.y = element_blank(), # Remove y-axis ticks axis.text.y = element_blank()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. â„¹ Please use `linewidth` instead. ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} parabola_plot ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](012-derivatives_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: . . . Initially, the height of the ball is [increasing]{.hi-green} over time Eventually, the height of the ball is [decreasing]{.hi-red} over time --- ## Intuition The sign of the derivative matters a ton! - An [increasing derivative]{.hi-green} means that the function is [going up]{.hi-green} - A [decreasing derivative]{.hi-red} means that the function is [going down]{.hi-red} . . . The [magnitude]{.h} also carries some significance: - A [small absolute value]{.hi} means that the [derivative is moving slowly]{.hi} - A [large absolute value]{.hii} means that the [derivative is moving rapidly]{.hii} . . . > [Note: I am talking about absoltue values so this applies to both positive and negative values. Because we use negatives, our intuition may challenged a bit but hopefully a future example will clear things up]{.h .note} --- ## Derivative Equal to Zero Functions can increase and decrease, which implies something very critical . . . > [Functions can have zero slope!]{.hii} This happens when the function switches from increasing to decreasing (and vice-versa) . . .
[But Why Does This Matter?]{.h} - The switch between positive and negative happens exactly when the function is at its maximum/minimum - And Economics is all about maximizing stuff! - Sometimes we minimize a function but the logic remains the same --- ## Bringing the Math to Economics Think about profits. As a firm, we want to maximize profits so we: :::: {.incremental} - Write down profits as a function of quantity produced - Take its derivative - Set that derivative (remember it is a function) equal to zero - Know how much quantity to produce :::: . . . Once we know what we are doing, the math is extremely simple. The hard part is understanding what we are doing, and then interpreting what a result of $x^{*} = 6$ means. --- ## How Do We Calculate Derivatives? You may already know how to take derivatives but prepare to receive a crash-course in derivative shortcuts . . . Starting with the basics: - $y$ will be a function of $x$ such that $y = f(x)$ - I will be using variables to show general cases so you can look back at how it's done . . . [We will go over the following:]{.hi} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="60%"} - Power Rule - Sum (and Difference) Rule - Constant Rule ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} - Log Rule - Chain Rule ::: :::: --- ## Power Rule This will be the most common derivative we will be using $$y = a \cdot x^{b}$$ . . . $$\dfrac{\delta y}{\delta x} = {\color{red}b} \cdot a \cdot x^{\color{red}{b-1}}$$ . . . For example: $$y = 5x^{3}$$ . . . $$\dfrac{\delta y}{\delta x} = {\color{red}3} \cdot 5 x^{\color{red}{3-1}} = 15x^{2}$$ --- ## Power Rule (Negative Exponent) Sometimes we will see factors with a negative exponent, like $x^{-3}$ for example As a rule of thumb, you should [always turn your negative exponents into positive ones]{.hii} Thankfully, its a simple process: . . . We just "invert" the negative factor (aka flip the fraction) $$x^{\color{red}-3} = \dfrac{1}{\color{red}{x^{3}}}$$ . . . The derivative works exactly the same way so we can begin with the derivative and then make it positive. --- ## Power Rule (Negative Exponent) So for $y = 5x^{-2}$ we have: $$\dfrac{\delta y}{\delta x} = -2 \cdot 5x^{-2-1} = -10x^{-3} = \dfrac{-10}{x^{3}}$$ I'll leave it to you to show yourself that making it $y = \dfrac{5}{x^{2}}$ gives the same result --- ## Power Rule (Fractional Exponent) A lot of the time we will have fractional exponents (or decimals) $$y = x^{1/5} = x^{0.2}$$ . . . $$\dfrac{\delta y}{\delta x} = \dfrac{1}{5} \cdot x^{1/5 - 1} = \dfrac{1}{5} x^{-4/5} = \dfrac{1}{5} \cdot \dfrac{1}{x^{4/5}}$$ . . .
$$\dfrac{\delta y}{\delta x} = 0.2 \cdot x^{0.2 - 1} = 0.2 \cdot x^{-0.8} = \dfrac{0.2}{x^{0.8}}$$ --- ## Power Rule (Exponent Equal to 1) Lastly, I'll remind you that every number has a default exponent of 1 That is to say, if we see $3x$ it is equivalent to $3x^{1}$ This helps us take the derivative using the [Power Rule]{.h} For example: $y = -3x$ . . . $$\dfrac{\delta y}{\delta x} = 1 \cdot -3x^{1-1} = -3x^{0} = -3$$ > [The key is to remember that any number with exponent 0 equals 1]{.hi} --- ## Sum (and Difference) Rule Sometimes our functions will have several parts, separated by $\pm$ To make it more general, I'll introduce some new notation: . . . - $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are both functions of $x$. . . . - $\dfrac{dy}{dx}$ refers to the overall derivative of $y$ - This just means that we will take the derivative of all factors that are functions of $x$ \begin{align*} y &= f(x) \pm g(x) \\ \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= f'(x) \pm g'(x) \end{align*} --- ## Sum (and Difference) Rule Let's look at a sum: $$y = x^{2} + 3x$$ . . . :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} \begin{align*} f(x) &= x^{2} \\ f'(x) &= 2x \end{align*} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} \begin{align*} g(x) &= 3x \\ g'(x) &= 3 \end{align*} ::: :::: . . . $$\dfrac{dy}{dx} = 2x + 3$$ --- ## Sum (and Difference) Rule How about a difference: $$y = x - 3x^{2}$$ . . . :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} \begin{align*} f(x) &= x \\ f'(x) &= 1 \end{align*} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} \begin{align*} g(x) &= 3x^{2} \\ g'(x) &= 6x \end{align*} ::: :::: . . . $$\dfrac{dy}{dx} = 1 - 6x$$ --- ## Constant Rule Important but straightforward $y = f(x) = a$, where $a$ is a constant ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = NULL, aes(x = NULL, y = NULL)) + xlim(0,10) + ylim(0,10) + labs(x = "x", y = "y") + theme_minimal() + theme(axis.text.x = element_blank(), # Remove x-axis ticks and labels axis.ticks.x = element_blank(), # Remove x-axis ticks, axis.ticks.y = element_blank(), # Remove y-axis ticks axis.text.y = element_blank()) p + geom_hline(yintercept = 5, linetype = "solid", color = "black", linewidth = 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](012-derivatives_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: . . . [$y \;$ does not change as $\; x \;$ increases, so the slope is 0]{.align-center} --- ## Log Rule One of the important functions we will see later uses the natural log function $ln(x)$ ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load the ggplot2 library if not already loaded library(ggplot2) # Create a data frame with x values data <- data.frame(x = seq(0.1, 5, by = 0.1)) # Generate x values from 0.1 to 5 # Add a new column with the natural logarithm of x data$ln_x <- log(data$x) # Create the ggplot object and plot the natural log function ggplot(data, aes(x = x, y = ln_x)) + geom_line(color = "black", size = 2) + xlim(0,5) + labs( x = "x", y = "ln(x)" ) + theme_minimal() + theme(axis.text.x = element_blank(), # Remove x-axis ticks and labels axis.ticks.x = element_blank(), # Remove x-axis ticks, axis.ticks.y = element_blank(), # Remove y-axis ticks axis.text.y = element_blank()) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](012-derivatives_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: It's primary use is that it increases at a decreasing rate which is math for it is always going up but by less and less every time --- ## Log Rule $$y = ln(x)$$ . . . $$\dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{x}$$ . . . How about? $$y = a \cdot ln(x)$$ . . . $$\dfrac{dy}{dx} = a \cdot \dfrac{1}{x} = \dfrac{a}{x}$$ --- ## Chain Rule - Sometimes there are multiple operations happening at the same time over a variable. Generelly, it looks like: $$y = f\left(g(x)\right)$$ . . . - We solve this by working from the outside layer to the inner most one, multiplying each time - Learning this is important for derivative math, but we will try to avoid them as much as possible --- ## Chain Rule {.smaller} $$y = \left(x^{3} + 2x\right)^{4}$$ . . . \begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= 4\left( x^{3} + 2x \right)^{4-1} \cdot \left( 3x^{3-1} + 2x^{1-1} \right) \\ &= 4 \left( x^{3} + 2x \right)^{3} \cdot \left( 3x^{2} + 2 \right) \end{align*} . . . How about? $$y = ln(x^{b})$$ . . . \begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \dfrac{1}{x^{b}} \cdot \dfrac{bx^{b-1}}{x^{b}} \\ &= bx^{b-1-b} = bx^{-1} = \dfrac{b}{x} \end{align*}
